issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.
status.name: Patch Available

fields.description:
After YARN-6216, the Container Update (which includes Resource increase and decrease) code-paths are mostly scheduler agnostic.

This JIRA tracks the final minor change needed in the FairScheduler. It also re-enables the {{TestAMRMClient#testAMRMClientWithContainerResourceChange}} test for the FairScheduler - which verifies that it works for the FairScheduler.
fields.summary: FairScheduler: Enable Container update CodePaths and container resize testcase

This message was automatically generated.

Two initial questions:
# I don't see anything in the tests that looks like it enables tests for container resizing for fair scheduler.  Were the tests there and just failing until this patch?
# Can we do something less prone to flakiness than sleeping 2000ms?

bq.  don't see anything in the tests that looks like it enables tests for container resizing for fair scheduler. Were the tests there and just failing until this patch?
In the patch, I removed the {{Assume.assumeTrue(schedulerName.equals(CapacityScheduler.class.getName()));}} line from the test. This was preventing it from being run for the FairScheduler.

bq. Can we do something less prone to flakiness than sleeping 2000ms?
To be honest, this is more required for the CapacityScheduler - which fails once in a while. The FaitScheduler passes without it.
We can make is less flaky, but that requires quite some more change (we can inject another dispatcher that ensure that events are processed etc.) - maybe we can address it in another JIRA ?

| (x) *{color:red}-1 overall{color}* |
\\
\\

I'll took a look when I get a chance.

[~asuresh] A quick question. If we only do node-local container update (we reject container allocations on a different node than the original node), what is the reason to set relaxLocality to true in the first place?

bq.  what is the reason to set relaxLocality to true in the first place?
This is actually an artefact of the FairScheduler. It throws an exception if the relax locality of a node local request is false (Relevant code is [here|https://github.com/apache/hadoop/blob/trunk/hadoop-yarn-project/hadoop-yarn/hadoop-yarn-server/hadoop-yarn-server-resourcemanager/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/yarn/server/resourcemanager/scheduler/fair/FSAppAttempt.java#L966-L971]). The CapacityScheduler does not really mind it.
Do we mean the warning message? I changed the relaxLocality to false, there was no exception.
Never mind. Talked with [~rkanter] offline. This is the correct way for fair scheduler. My understanding was incorrect.
